Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Developing integrated trait-based scaling theory to predict community change and forest function in light of global change
Award.AbstractNarration:
Tropical forests store an enormous amount of carbon, with the Amazon alone accounting for 10% of the Earth's primary productivity. Changes in tropical forest productivity in response to drought are an important feedback in the carbon cycle; yet, we currently have a very incomplete understanding of how biomass, productivity, and species composition of these forests respond to changes in temperature and water availability. This project will take a new approach to understanding tropical forest drought responses by focusing on the relationships between plant functional traits, metabolic scaling theory, and climate drivers. Functional traits are easily measureable metrics that allow us to better predict plant growth, reproduction, and forest change. Metabolic scaling theory describes the relationships between the size of an organism, its growth rate, and temperature. This project will attempt to significantly advance our understanding of how tropical ecosystems respond to changes in temperature and precipitation. Researchers will use scaling theory to provide a predictive framework that links forest responses to drought with well understood plant traits measured using novel ground and remote sensing technology.

This project will assess changes in productivity in response to drought, as well as tree mortality and forest dieback. This will be accomplished using both field measurements as well as pre-existing LIDAR and hyperspectral remote sensing data from forests across an elevation gradient in the Peruvian Amazon. Specifically, researchers will use a suite of plant functional traits to provide detailed, 3D maps of forest canopy structure and the spatial distribution of traits. The novel scaling theory developed with these data (Trait Driver Theory, TDT) will then be used to predict ecosystem function from changes in trait distributions over time in response to drought. The project will also involve a field experiment to simulate drought with throughfall collectors to help parameterize TDT model functions. The TDT results will also be compared to predictions from the ecosystem demography model ED2. Model code, images, and algorithms will be made available in public repositories, and any new plant functional trait data will be added to global databases. The project will provide training for several post-doctoral researchers, undergraduate students, and K-12 science teachers and will use the GEM Network Geoweb Portal for outreach to the general public.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A major goal of this project is to predict regions that will be most endangered by climate change -- especially in response to temperature change or drought -- in large forest regions like the Amazon but also across the globe and many parts of the US. In particular, we want to improve all such estimates and such approaches by looking at more information about traits (such as leaf area or nitrogen content) and climate factors that are closely connected to plant growth and survival. This will allow the field to continue to move beyond just average traits and climate factors and into the variance and ranges in traits and climate factors.

In a paper published in Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences, we detail how to decompose which plant traits are affected by which climate drivers. We assess this across a set of data that spans altitudinal and latitudinal gradients. We also distinguish between which distribution moments -- mean, variance, skewness, kurtosis -- are driven by which climate factors -- which we also broke down by aspects such as mean and variance. One of our key results is that variation in temperature has as large or more of an effect on traits as does average temperature. This is crucial because most studies with regard to climate change and biological systems have focused on average temperature and have just recently become more focused on the variation or range in temperature.

A second major effort is to devise best methods for how remote-sensing data--collected by plane or satellite--can be used to estimate Net Primary Productivity (NPP) for sites, including results for sites in the Amazon. We show that remotely-sensed estimates can be as accurate as ground-based methods, and we also carefully and explicitly explain how to go from remote-sensing data to estimates of NPP. In particular, we grapple with choices of how to estimate biomass along with tree size and layers of canopy and thus light attenuation through the canopy. Moreover, we examine the effects of different spatial scales--from meters to landscapes--for estimates, which traits are most informative, and what additional data would be best to collect in the future. Finally, we compare results with satellite-based methods and show the advantages of our methods both in terms of capturing qualitative trends and quantitative precision.

To summarize, our three biggest impacts are first that we are using a data-grounded and theory-informed approach to develop a more detailed and nuanced picture of how plant traits are driven by climatic factors. Second, we are accomplishing this first impact partly by shifting focus away from just average traits and climate factors, and in addition, looking at other information such as variance and skewness. This goes hand-in-hand with our development of Trait Driver Theory (TDT) that is naturally formulated in terms of this additional information and the connections between the climatic factors and the traits such as Specific Leaf Area (SLA). Finally, by building on the results and works in impacts 1 and 2, we are taking a good first step towards enabling the use of large amounts of remote-sensing data --from airplanes and satellites -- to be used to estimate traits and future Net Primary Productivity (NPP) based on projected changes in the climate related to temperature and drought.
